subject: Medicine
title: The Hippocratic Oath
description: A short lesson to help you apply The Hippocratic Oath.

hook.text: Doctors have sworn to 'first, do no harm' for 2,400 years. But the original oath also banned surgery.

buildup.text: The Hippocratic Oath is the oldest code of medical ethics, written in ancient Greece around 400 BCE.

discovery.text: It established core principles: help patients, avoid harm, maintain confidentiality, and teach the next generation.

twist.text: Most modern doctors don't swear the original oath. Updated versions reflect current values and medical realities.

climax.text: The oath's spirit endures: medicine exists to serve patients, not profit, power, or personal convenience.

punchline.text: The oldest rule in medicine is still the best.

quiz.question: What surprising element was in the original Hippocratic Oath?
options: It banned doctors from performing surgery
It required doctors to treat patients for free
It only applied to male physicians
